options.text: <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>  channels are closed and  <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>   channels are open inside the nerve membrane.

<math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>  gate closes and  <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>  gate opens inside the nerve membrane.

Both  <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>  and  <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>  gates are closed inside the nerve membrane.
Both gates remain open inside the nerve membrane.

solution.text: The resting state is polarized state. This contains sodium extracellularly while potassium ions are present inside the axons. As impulse arrives Sodium channels open and thus there is influx of sodium. This is state of action potential or depolarization. This continues for only  <math><mn>0.5</mn></math>  msec after which potassium channels open and sodium channels close. This causes efflux of potassium and this is known as repolarization.
